author: Claire Heaney
title: Family’s eagle eye for quality
text:
LAUNCHED in Clifton Hill between the Depression and World War II, Eagle Remac has ridden the ups and downs of manufacturing.
“We’ve had three tough years, but the past year has been buoyant,” director Peter Gray said.
“It has helped that the Australian dollar has nosedived. Our product is very good and we have hit a sweet spot on price and quality.”
Mr Gray and brother Paul are the custodians of the third-generation furniture business founded by their great uncle Reginald Muir. It moved around the inner city before relocating to Thomastown in 1965.
“During the war they were instructed to build coffins,” Mr Gray said.
At one time, Remac operated in tandem with a steelworks business called Eagle Tubular Furniture.
The now closed steelworks supplied the tubular steel used in the manufacturing of Laminex tables and chairs, which were popular from the 1950s.
“I think every second beach house in Rye probably still has one of those dining sets,” said Mr Gray of the furniture that is now sought out by retro hunters and hipster cafes.
Mr Gray said their electrician father, George, was talked into joining the company in the early 1950s.
The business has always wholesaled its products.
In the past, it was to household names such as Patersons and Maples. These days, its main stockists include Snooze, Forty Winks, Domayne and independent retailers.
The business was buoyant right up to the 1980s but started to struggle as backyard operators, working in their homes with no overheads, were able to undercut it on office and home furniture.
“We found the only margin between them and us was the cost of the material. They were working for nearly nothing,” Mr Gray said.
“We were employing between 50 and 60 people, turning over heaps of stuff, but not making any money.”
Mr Gray said they decided to relaunch back into the domestic furniture market with a designer product.
“I wasn’t a designer. It just evolved. It was quite a learning curve and it wasn’t always smooth sailing,” he said.
He said one bed design was met with horror by a potential retailer.
“He looked at it and said. ‘My God, what have you been smoking?’,” Mr Gray said.
In his defence, Mr Gray said the bed was modern, with clean lines and could stand up well, even today.
“It was a good seller but was cutting-edge at the time.”
He said there was currently an appetite for Australian-made goods.
“I think there is a very strong turn back to Australian-made by customers and retailers who realise we have something to offer.
“We have flexibility. We can give choice of colour and finishes.
“We can react quickly to what people want and we can do short runs.
“All of a sudden, people have worked out that local manufacturing has benefits.”
Tomorrow is Family Business Day.
